pageContext.claim: “You look at the Washington Post or the New York Times, I can never get a good story. I mean, you look at this horrible thing that took place today, it's really -- is it subversion? Is it treason? It's a horrible thing”
pageContext.analysis: Trump poses this as a question, but it’s not even one. Treason against the United States is limited under Article III of the Constitution to "levying war against the United States, or adhering to their enemies, giving them aid and comfort." Writing an unflattering editorial about the President is pretty remote from either of those categories. “There is a very big difference between disloyalty to a President and disloyalty to the United States,” said Carlton F.W. Larson is a professor of law at the University of California at Davis and author of the forthcoming book in treason. “And it was precisely to prevent any such confusion that the framers drafted Article III as carefully as they did.”
